objdescid.origination: William Blake author, inventor, delineator, etcher, printer, colorist

objinfo.numberobj: 17This copy does not contain Bentley plate 3.
objinfo.objorder: plates 1-2, 4-18The plate numbers given here are the Bentley numbers. The inscriptions added to many of the plates, plus the writing on the verso of the title page (object 2, Bentley plate 2), are available under Related Works in the Archive; see the note on Medium, below.
objinfo.objsize: ranging between 23.9 x 17.3 cm. and 23.1 x 16.4 cm.
objinfo.numberleaves: 11Objects 1 and 2 (Bentley plates 1 and 2) are printed on the rectos of single leaves; the other plates are printed recto/verso.
objinfo.medium: Relief and white-line etching with color printing and hand coloring. Objects 1, 3-11, 13-15, 17 (Bentley plates 1, 4-12, 14-16, 18) and the verso of object 2 (Bentley plate 2) bear pen and ink inscriptions. Objects 7-9, 13, 15, 17 (Bentley plates 8-10, 14, 16, 18) also bear brief pencil inscriptions.The pen and ink inscriptions, attributed by Bentley (page 159) and others to George Cumberland, are available as Related Works in the Archive for each object on which they appear. Most are quoted from Edward Bysshe, The Art of English Poetry, a popular and often reprinted anthology of English verse, arranged by subject and first published in 1702. Shared textual variants indicate that Bysshe was the source, as first pointed out in S. Foster Damon, William Blake: His Philosophy and Symbols (1924), pages 347-51. We have surveyed several editions of Bysshe through the ninth (1762), the last edition known to us that was published prior to the etching of Europe a Prophecy. The pencil inscriptions, also available under Related Works in the Archive, would appear to have been written in a hand different from the pen and ink inscriptions and may be of a later date. The leaves are stamped on their rectos with a British Museum collection mark which, on some objects, extends into the image.
objinfo.inkcolor: Objects 7-8 (Bentley plates 8-9) in brown, all other objects in blue-green. The manuscript ink (see the note on Medium, above) is now dark brown.
objinfo.watermark: I TaylorThe watermark appears only on the leaves bearing objects 3-4 and 13-14 (Bentley plates 4-5 and 14-15).
objinfo.pennednumbers: 1-15The penned numbers appear on objects 3-17 (Bentley plates 4-18). The odd numbers appear top right, the even numbers top left.
objinfo.binding: mounted in heavy paper mats bound in red morocco with Visions of the Daughters of Albion copy A.Both works were formerly bound together in half green morocco. The present binding was created in 1969.

provenance.name: British Museum, Department of Prints and Drawings
provenance.note: Acquired, probably directly from Blake in 1796, by Ozias Humphry; apparently lent by Humphry to George Cumberland, who added the pen and ink inscriptions; bequeathed by Humphry to his son, William Upcott, in 1810; sold after Upcott's death at Evans, the London auction house, 15 June 1846, lot 277, with The Large Book of Designs copy A and The Small Book of Designs copy A "inserted," and with America a Prophecy copy H in the same lot (£7.2s.6d. to the dealer R. H. Evans); possibly acquired by Francis Turner Palgrave; acquired by the British Museum on 25 June 1859.

repository.addressline: Email, Department of Prints and Drawings: prints@britishmuseum.org
URL, Department of Prints and Drawings: http://www.britishmuseum.org/the_museum/departments/prints_and_drawings.aspx

desc.objtitle: , object 1 full view including inscriptions (Bentley 1, Erdman i, Keynes i)
, object 1 bottom inscription (Bentley 1, Erdman i, Keynes i)

objnote.p: This pen and ink inscription appears below the image. The lines are quoted from John Milton, Paradise Lost (1667), Book 7, lines 224-31. We have not been able to find these lines in the editions of Edward Bysshe, The Art of English Poetry, we have surveyed.

lg.l: In his hand, he took, the Golden Compasses, prepared
In Gods eternal store, to circumscribe
This Universe, and all created things.
One foot he center'dcentered, and the other turn'dturned,
Round through the vast profundity obscure,
And said, thus far extend, thus far thy bounds
This be thy just circumference, O World!Bentley reads "world" for "World" (Writings volume 1, page 708).
Milton

desc.objtitle: , object 2 verso inscription (Bentley 2, Erdman ii, Keynes ii)

objnote.p: This pen and ink inscription is written on the verso of object 2 (Bentley plate 2), the title page. It refers to object 3 (Bentley plate 4), which it faces. The lines are quoted from Ann Radcliffe, The Mysteries of Udolpho (1794), volume 3, chapter 7. These lines do not appear in Edward Bysshe, The Art of English Poetry, for we have found no edition of Bysshe published later than 1762 other than reprints of earlier editions.

lg.l: The Pilgrim, by Ann RadcliffRadcliffe.
Slow oe'rover the ApannineApannine with bleeding feet,"Apannine" was rewritten once or twice. Bentley reads "Apinine" for "Apannine"(Writings volume 1, page 708).
A Patient Pilgrim wound his lonely way,Bentley reads "patient" for "Patient" (Writings volume 1, page 708).
To deck the Lady of Loretto's seat,Bentley reads "Lorretto's" for "Loretto's" (Writings volume 1, page 708).
With all the little wealth his zeal could pay.
From mountain tops cold died the evening ray,
And stretch'tstretched in twilight slept the vale below,Bentley reads "stretch'd" for "stretch't" (Writings volume 1, page 708).
And now the last last purple streaks of day"last last": i.e., presumably, a slip for "last".
Along the melancholy wWest fade slow.
High o'erover his head the restless Pines complain,
As on their summits rolls the brezebreeze of nightBentley reads "breeze" for "breze" (Writings volume 1, page 708).
Beneath, the hoarse stream chides the rocks in vain,The word "hoarse" was written over a word that has been washed out and is now illegible.
The Pilgrim pauses on the dizzy heights,
Then to the vale his cautious steps he prest,
For there a Hermits Cross was dimly seenBentley reads "cross" for "Cross" (Writings volume 1, page 708).
Cresting the rock, and there his limbs might rest,
(cheerdcheered in the good mans cave by faggot sheen).
On leafy beds, nor guile his sleep molest,
Unhappy lLuke! he trusts a treacherous clue!
Behind the Cliff the lurking Robber stood,
No friendly moon his Giant shadow threw,Bentley reads "the" for "his" (Writings volume 1, page 708).
Athwart the road, to save the Pilgrims blood;
On as he went a vesper hymn he sang,
The Hymn that nightly soothed him to repose;
Fierce on his harmless prey thae Ruffian sprang,
The Pilgrim bleeds to death, his eyelids close,
Yet his meek spirit knew no vengeful care,
But dying for his Murld'rerMurderer breathed a sainted prayrprayer!

desc.objtitle: , object 3 full view including inscriptions (Bentley 4, Erdman 1, Keynes 1)

objnote.p: These inscriptions appear above the image. The first line is written in pen and ink; the second line, in pencil, may have been written by a different hand; the third line is written in pen and ink by Blake.

desc.objtitle: , object 4 full view including inscriptions (Bentley 5, Erdman 2, Keynes 2)

objnote.p: This pen and ink inscription appears above the image. The lines of verse, exclusive of the title, are quoted from Samuel Garth, The Dispensary (1699), Book 6, lines 103-06. These lines are printed in Edward Bysshe, The Art of English Poetry, under the heading "Winds." The fifth line is written in pen and ink by Blake.

lg.l: Storms, Tempests. &c
He views with horror next the noisy cave
Where with hoarse din imprisondimprisoned tempests rave
Where clam'rousclamorous Hurricanes attempt their flight
Or whirling in tumultuous Eddies fight.

objnote.p: This pen and ink inscription appears below the image. The lines are quoted from Sir Richard Blackmore, Prince Arthur (1695), Book 6. These lines are printed in Edward Bysshe, The Art of English Poetry, under the heading "Storm."

lg.l: This orbs wide frame with the convulsion shakes,
Oft opens in the Storm, and often cracks,Bentley reads "storm" for "Storm" (Writings volume 1, page 709).
Horror, aAmazement, and Despair appear,
In all the hideous forms that Mortals fear.Bentley reads "mortals" for "Mortals" (Writings volume 1, page 709).

desc.objtitle: , object 5 full view including inscriptions (Bentley 6, Erdman 3, Keynes 3)

objnote.p: This pen and ink inscription appears above the image. It serves as a title for the design below. The second line is written in pen and ink by Blake.

desc.objtitle: , object 5 right margin inscription (Bentley 6, Erdman 3, Keynes 3)

objnote.p: This pen and ink inscription appears in the margin to the right of the image. The lines are condensed from Nicholas Rowe, The Fair Penitent (1703), Act 3, Scene 1, lines 6-8. These lines are printed in Edward Bysshe, The Art of English Poetry, under the heading "Planet."

lg.l: Like some malignant
Planet that lowrslowers
upon the world.
Rowe.

objnote.p: This pen and ink inscription appears below the image. The first four lines are quoted from John Milton, Paradise Lost (1667), Book 2, lines 708-10. The next four lines are quoted from Alexander Pope's translation of Homer's Iliad (1715-20), Book 4, lines 1-3, 104, 107, 108. The final two lines are adapted from William Shakespeare, Henry VI, Part I (1598), Act I, Scene 1, lines 2-3. All three passages are printed in Edward Bysshe, The Art of English Poetry, under the heading "Comet."

lg.l: He, like a Comet, burndburned,Bentley reads "burned" for "burnd" (Writings volume 1, page 709).
That fires the length of Ophiucus huge
In th' Arctick ArcticSkyesky; and from his horrid hair
Shakes Pestilence and war. ___ milton
As the Red Comet from Saturnius sent
To fright the nations with a dire portent
With sweeping Glories glides along in air
And shakes the sparkles from his blazing hair.
Homer.
Comets impartinzg change to times and statesBentley reads "importing" for "imparting" (Writings volume 1, page 709).
Brandish your golden tresses in the Skies.Bentley reads "to" for "in" (Writings volume 1, page 709).
ShakespearShakespeare.

desc.objtitle: , object 6 full view including inscriptions (Bentley 7, Erdman 4, Keynes 4)

objnote.p: This pen and ink inscription appears below the image. The first line is quoted from John Dryden's translation of Virgil, The Aeneid (1697), Book 6, line 409. The remaining lines are quoted from John Dryden's translation of the story of "Meleager and Atalanta" from Book 8 of Ovid's Metamorphoses, published in Dryden's Fables Ancient and Modern (1700), lines 316-17. Both passages are printed in Edward Bysshe, The Art of English Poetry, under the heading "Ghost."

lg.l: Forms without body and impassive air
Thin shades the sports of winds are toss'ttossedBentley reads "sport" for "sports," and "toss'd" for "toss't" (Writings volume 1, page 710).
O'erOver dreary Plains, or tread the burning coast. Bentley reads "plains" for "Plains" (Writings volume 1, page 710).

desc.objtitle: , object 7 full view including inscriptions (Bentley 8, Erdman 5, Keynes 5)

objnote.p: These inscriptions appear above the image. The first line is written in pen and ink; the second line, in pencil, may have been written by a different hand; the third line is written in pen and ink by Blake.

This pen and ink inscription appears below the image. The lines are quoted from William Shakespeare, Henry VI, Part 2 (1600), Act 5, Scene 2, lines 33-34. We have not been able to find these lines in the editions of Edward Bysshe, The Art of English Poetry, we have surveyed.

lg.l: O war! thou Son of Hell,
Whom angry heavens do make their minister!

desc.objtitle: , object 8 full view including inscriptions (Bentley 9, Erdman 6, Keynes 6)

objnote.p: These inscriptions appear above the image. The title "Famine" is written in pen and ink; the second line is in pencil, and would appear to be written in a hand different from all those in pen and ink. The third line is written in pen and ink by Blake.

This pen and ink inscription appears below the image. The lines are quoted from John Dryden, The Indian Emperour (1697), Act 4, Scene 2, lines 33-36. These lines are printed in Edward Bysshe, The Art of English Poetry, under the heading "Famine."

lg.l: Famine so fierce that whats denied mans use
Even deadly Plants and herbs of pois'nouspoisonous juiceBentley reads "plants" for "Plants" (Writings volume 1, page 710).
Will Hunger Eat— and to prolong our breath
We greedily devour our certain Death.
Dryden

desc.objtitle: , object 9 full view including inscriptions (Bentley 10, Erdman 7, Keynes 7)

objnote.p: These inscriptions appear above the image. The first line is written in pen and ink; the second line, in pencil, may have been written by a different hand; the third line is written in pen and ink by Blake.

This pen and ink inscription appears below the image. The lines are quoted from William Mason, "On the Death of a Lady," lines 1-4, first published in his Elegies (1763). These lines are not printed in the editions of Edward Bysshe, The Art of English Poetry, we have surveyed, for they were published a year after the appearance of the last edition of Bysshe published before Europe a Prophecy.

lg.l: The midnight clock has toll'dtolled, and hark! the Bell
Of Death beats Slow!__ heard ye the note profound?
It pauses now, and now with rising knell,
Flings to the hollow gale its sullen sound.Bentley reads "the sullen" for "its sullen" (Writings volume 1, page 710).
Mason.

desc.objtitle: , object 10 full view including inscriptions (Bentley 11, Erdman 8, Keynes 8)

objnote.p: This pen and ink inscription appears below the image. The lines are quoted from John Dryden's translation of Virgil, The Aeneid (1697), Book 2, lines 408-09. These lines are printed in Edward Bysshe, The Art of English Poetry, under the heading "Flood."

lg.l: Thus Deluges descending on the Plains
Sweep o'erover the yellow year &c,
Dryden.

desc.objtitle: , object 11 full view including inscriptions (Bentley 12, Erdman 9, Keynes 9)

objnote.p: These inscriptions appear above the image. The first line is written in pen and ink; the second line is written in pen and ink by Blake.

desc.objtitle: , object 13 full view including inscriptions (Bentley 14, Erdman 11, Keynes 11)

objnote.p: These inscriptions appear above the image. The first line is written in pen and ink; the second line, in pencil, may have been written by a different hand; the third line is written in pen and ink by Blake.

texthead.l: Papal, SuperstitionThe lowercase "p" in "Papal" has been partially erased. The whole word has been written over another erased word, tentatively read as "Pagan" in William Blake, The Continental Prophecies, ed. D. W. Doerrbecker (London: The William Blake Trust / The Tate Gallery, 1995), page 210.

desc.objtitle: , object 14 full view including inscriptions (Bentley 15, Erdman 12, Keynes 12)

objnote.p: This pen and ink inscription appears below the image. The lines are quoted from John Dryden's opera libretto, King Arthur (1691), Act 3, lines 329, 330, 332, 333. These lines are printed in Edward Bysshe, The Art of English Poetry, under the heading "Dungeon."

lg.l: Them to a Dungeons depth I sent, fast bound,
Where stow'dstowed with snakes and adders now they lodge,
The rats brush oerover their faces with their tails,
And croaking Paddocks crawl upon thier limbs."thier": i.e., presumably, a slip for "their". Bentley reads "their" for "thier" (Writings volume 1, page 711).
Dryden.

desc.objtitle: , object 15 full view including inscriptions (Bentley 16, Erdman 13, Keynes 13)

objnote.p: These inscriptions appear above the image. The first line is written in pen and ink; the second line, in pencil, may have been written by a different hand; the third line is written in pen and ink by Blake.

This pen and ink inscription appears below the image. The lines are adapted from John Fletcher (and possibly William Shakespeare), The Two Noble Kinsmen (1634), Act 2, Scene 2, lines 40-45. We have not been able to find these lines in the editions of Edward Bysshe, The Art of English Poetry, we have surveyed.

lg.l: This is all ourmy world __ weI shall nothing know
Nothing hear, but the Clock that tells ourmy woes,"Clock": there may be a slip of the pen or a partly overwritten letter at the end of the word.
The vine shall grow, but weI shall never see it,
Summer shall come, and with her all delights,
But dead cold winter still inhabit here.

desc.objtitle: , object 17 full view including inscriptions (Bentley 18, Erdman 15, Keynes 15)

objnote.p: These inscriptions appear above the image. The first line is written in pen and ink; the second line, in pencil, may have been written by a different hand; the third line is written in pen and ink by Blake.

This pen and ink inscription appears below the image. The lines are quoted from Sir Richard Blackmore, Prince Arthur (1695), Book 3. These lines are printed in Edward Bysshe, The Art of English Poetry, under the heading "Fire."

lg.l: __ Th'impetuousThe impetuous flames with lawless powrpower advance,
On ruddy wings the bright destruction flies,
follow'dfollowed with ruoin and distressful cries,
The flaky Plague spreads swiftly with the wind
And gastlyghastly desolation howls behind.
